title: Making educational and crowdsourcing games more comparable

So the game metrics form into three different categories.
This player focused metrics, community focused metrics and item or annotation focus metrics.
Now, if I kind of stray into language annotation, that's because what my games do, so apologies for that.

So when we have a look at player metrics, these are metrics that really understand the interaction between the player, the platform and any kind of outside activity that's going on during a given time period.
So for example, advertising.
And the first one is cost per acquisition, so this is the cost to actually get a player to start playing your game now in free to play speech.
That's cost per acquisition, and that's basically the advertising budget over, say, a month divided by the number of new users that you get to your platform.
OK, that's a cost per acquisition.
But it's not quite that simple because obviously when you have an advertising campaign, it's not just run from one day to another date.
Well, it is, but you have a spillover effect, so people will still see that advert.
Perhaps people start emailing it to each other so you get a viral effect.
So you've got this kind of spillover virality going on.
And how do you detect between new and active users?
So how do you tell if someone seen the adverts?
Oh I remember that game.
I'll come back and play that game.
OK, so there are issues related to all of these metrics.
This isn't to give you a definitive.
This is what we should do.
This is to say, these metrics that exist and maybe we should think about sharing them.
So the next one is lifetime judgments.
So in free to play speech, that's the customer lifetime value.
So how much money do they give you over the course of their engagement with your platform, minus the cost to get them onto your platform?
In in our kind of in a kind of world, that's just the total contribution to the game.
So how much contribution?
How many annotations or labels have they contributed?
Can we really put a monetary value on that contribution?

If we could, then we could then talk about we could reconcile that with the cost per acquisition, but that's slightly slightly complicated thing to do, and again, you have complications of returning users and the same actual physical person having different accounts, so there's complications with that.
The next metric is average judgment per person, and this is a very common one.

When you see free to play games called our ARPU average revenue per user and what that is is you take all of the revenue from the game over a time period divided by the total active users and that's a big kind of headline figure and in terms of our games it would be the average contribution over a period of time divided by the total active players.
But as I'm sure most of you aware, have built crowdsourcing platforms.
There is a zipfian distribution of work, so some people people contribute a lot.
Some people contribute a little bit and this figure is only headline figure.
It disguises that distribution.
And then the final one is the average lifetime play.
So how long the players continue to contribute over there over the time?
So what is the definition of a lifetime?
Players play for a couple of months and then stop playing and then six months pass and they rejoin again.
Is that a new user is the same user?
And then there is how do you measure time?
So do you measure in that I'm actually engaged with the game?
Or is it actual physical time that elapsed?

In terms of their total contribution, is tiny compared to the really big high contributors the high spenders, so the top 10% contributed nearly 50% of revenue to these mobile games.
So you see the zipfian distribution of contribution in all these.
Anne.
In all these platforms.

9% of the people engage with it and 1% of the people actually create the content.
So lots of different variations of that of that type of rule.

Be silly.

Maybe you need lots of opinions.

But it's these metrics that allow you to understand that and allow you to adjust your platform accordingly.
So if you look at the Community metrics, so this is a very common one.
Monthly active users and it's used for free to play.
That's simply the number of users who contribute in a calendar month.

Although the definition of active varies, so it could just be someone that logs in that's active, or it could be something that actually produces a useful contribution or paste something into the into the platform.
And then these two 2 idea idea idea is called retention and churn which are opposite of each other.
So the percentage of players who continue to play the game is retention and the percentage of players who stop is what's called churn.
And they're very commonly used in free to play as well.
So these kind of metrics allow you to see how fast you get your game or your platform is growing and how sticky your game is.
So how often do the players come back and actually keep playing on these games?
And I suppose, more importantly, are the incentives or the motivational methods that you deploy?
Are they working so quite often in our game we have us like a top scoring prize.
If you like like Amazon vouchers or something like that, and that tends to get people working a lot more.

So this is the first 12 months of the phrase detective game, and this dark line here is the.
New players that we gained and the dashed line is active players and a month 15 or 14.
We did a big promotion and had some prizes and you can see a big jump in the contribution.
So that's monthly active users plotted on a graph, and that's much more useful than, say, a cumulative growth chart which you see on the right hand side, which is from the same time period.
You don't really see you see a little jump there, but don't really see the kind of difference in a month by month effect that you can see from the monthly active user type plots.
Finally coming to item metrics.
So there's this idea of using these metrics to test the overall performance of the system, and these are the ones that we've really used to compare systems against each other.
Now, throughput was the one that von an presented in his his paper 10 years ago as a sort of headline metric.
He didn't propose it as a metric for everyone's game, you just reported it, but I think it's a very good one to you.
Use.
So cost per judgment is the cost to get a useful contribution from a player, and so that's the financial cost of engagement of the user.
So you might be spending money on prizes or advertising.
These kind of things to get people to actually play the game and to make a contribution to your system.

There's also the ongoing cost of the project or the platform, so your language learning platform, for example, might have to employ teachers and researchers to develop and the platform and for the software hosting all that kind of stuff, so that's that's the ongoing cost for useful contributions.
New platform.

The judgment required how many useful judgments are required to complete an item, so it might be that the contributions from a number of people you decide to throw them away because somehow you've measured that that person is not very good at the game, so you disregard their contribution.
So there is a wastage from spam training users attention slips, that kind of stuff.
It also depends on the aggregation methods you use, and there's lots of starting from majority voting onwards to Bayesian and network based things.
You can do for aggregation, and that's a whole whole different workshop entirely.
And it also depends on the difficulty of the items that you're that you're collecting data on.

So if you're crowdsourcing about a difficult language task, if you're doing a language translation task from English to Swahili or something where there's very few people who are able to do that well, you may have to look at the skill of players, and this may adjust the number of judgments that you require to actually get something done.
Then that allows us to get a headline statistically of the cost per item.
So this is what you would put into a Journal Journal, a project application if you like, and you would say normally we would collect this data in this fashion.
We employ some annotators and it costs this much, but we can use crowdsourcing and we estimate that it will cost this much and that is how you calculate it.
So it's the cost per item, so the cost of completely annotating a single item is the cost per judgment times the number of judgments you need.
And then you multiply that by the number of how much data you require from your project, and that's that's how you can build a budget from that.
And that's also compatible across not only compatible compatible across games, but also a different approaches as well.

So sometimes if you employ expert annotators, that might be different to employing students to do annotation that be slightly cheaper, but perhaps you'd employ three students rather than one expert or these kind of things so you can compare different approaches.
And then finally throughput which I mentioned before, which is the number of completed items you can produce in an hour.

So again, this gives you an idea of scalability of what you're trying to do, because if you say I want to annotate this 100 million word corpus, but it takes me, it takes me a day to get a document finished, then you multiply that up and you realize that it takes you take your 100 years to actually get your number of things done, so the throughput allows you an assessment of time, and then the this on the cost per item gives you an estimate of budget as well.
So these community metrics.
These sort of big headline platform metrics can give you an idea of whether your system can produce data fast enough.
How many players you need, and also whether a different approach might be better.
So micro working.

And it's much better to use micro working.
Then develop a game or a bigger platform where you only need a small amount of data.
That's worth considering.

So yeah, couple of issues that we've come across in our project and then a couple of design ideas so.
When you're doing crowdsourcing, quite often you're collecting a majority voting opinion because you only have a single answer.

You have one correct answer and all the other answers are not as good or they're incorrect, OK, and that's you can compare that to an export an expert, so your game produces one answer and you compare that to an expert in a language learning sense.
You have the correct translation or the correct the correct interpretation of a sentence, and the language learner tries to put that in, and if they get it right, then yes.
And if they don't, then they have to be given some more training materials.
Few systems can produce a probabilistic answer set with ambiguity ambiguity.

That's what we're actually working on, and actually in language learning you might want to have that so you have the optimal answer, but perhaps if they put something not quite so good, it's still kind of correct, so they still get some recognition, and then they just get a bit of a bit of tuition as to how to make their sort of language learning outputs a bit better.

The thing is, it's very hard to distinguish between a correct minority opinion from an actual error, and this is what we found in our project we're working on at the moment is that if you have someone who's very good who puts in a very good answer and yet a lot of people put in not such a good answer.
Which one do you go for?
I don't know the answers, by the way.
These are ongoing research questions.

And so you have this value of a single good player versus many bad players, and the ability of your crowd generally has a very, very big impact on the kind of data that you're collecting in the kind of crowdsourcing that you can do.
One of the other issues that we've come across is the use of contextual real world knowledge that's required by the task.
So this is also something that plays into language learning as well as if you ask a question, you assume that people would know the answer.
So when we do anaphoric coreference in our games we were to talk about the Prime Minister of the UK and Theresa May.
We would assume that everyone knows that but not everyone would know that.
And it's the same with language learners as well.
There's certain contextual knowledge that you have to make explicit for people to solve the task.

And then a topic for discussion really is, can language learners provide useful language data and mean Karen started arguing about this on the way over to lunch and on the way back, and no doubt will continue discussing.
But it's an important question.
So can people second language learners or people who are perhaps not as good at the language as others and so non experts can they still provide useful language data.
And what we're trying to collect here is there's two types of human knowledge.
There's human knowledge that you have collected to the real world, knowledge, contextualization, knowledge, that kind of stuff.

But there's also the ability to solve problems using kind of human brain power and a lot of our language data collection uses this kind of real world understanding of language rather than the human brain power, whereas for example, the image processing an image labeling stuff often uses human brainpower.
So there's those different kinds of human computation going on there as well.
But this is the project that we're working on at the moment.
It's called the disagreements and language Interpretation project as a five year 2.5 million euro projects that Massimo was funded for.

Text.

We have a number of work packages as all good projects do so one of them is to is to develop games with a purpose and platforms for anaphora and then of the analyzing the kind of data that we get and our project is actually gone from simply collecting data to actually now trying to engage language learners in not any identifying in Africa.

They're very hard to explain what they are to a non native speaker.
You have to show them examples and that's what we can do in this in our work here that we've been working on.
We haven't got a number of games on the development of phrase detectives was our first one and that's everything is under development.
But that one's been going for 10 years.
We have tile attack which investigates.
It's a it's a player motivation platform.
Really, it cannot be changed around to test what actually engages players, but it does named entity tagging.
We have word gems, which is a game for introducing the concept of noun phrases, and we develop that because we introduce these games to a bunch of language learners at Queen Mary.
And I and we kept saying the word noun phrase.
And then perhaps it was a noun phrase, and I said, you know what noun phrases don't, you know?
So we actually failed at the very first hurdle of engaging language learners 'cause we were using terminology they didn't understand.
So we produce some lower level games that actually introduce these terms and allows users to engage with them.
And then our final game is warming go, which is quite a complex language learning game, but it's specifically geared up for language learners and it collects data through engagement.

But it also has non data collection games, so it has things like word searches and crosswords and all this kind of stuff that are built from the text we're collecting data on and it allows language learners to actually do more traditional language learning tasks while still providing some kind of data and engaging with the games as well.
All these games are released on the Lingo Boingo Portfol Portal, which is the.
Linguistic data consortium.
an American partner of ours.
They are promoting these these games with us and that we are actually trying to collaborate with them to combine the metrics to compare these games as well.
So I said I'd give you some ideas about how to engage people in platforms.

I am very fortunate to work with Richard Bartle, who's the guy who invented multi user Dungeons, so if any of you are old enough to have A to go to University or school and they had a computer room where all the birds went either like a BBC or Apple Mac or something like that really old one, these are the games that people were playing.
So you go on and you type in.
I'm going to kill the dwarf and then say you have killed the Wolf.
That comes in these multi user Dungeons.
He invented them.
And when he invented them, he notice that there were four different characteristics of players that were coming out.
There were people who were achievers and they like to achieve power and status and their fun and enjoyment from engaging.
The platform comes from leveling up and gaining points.
You have explorers, people who like to figure out the game to like find the full extent of the game and collect those kind of little hidden Easter eggs within within games and platforms.
You have people that you have socializes people who like to engage with the other users in the game.

And then you have people who are killers and killers, that people who typically like to do things that you don't expect, they cause trouble and they interact, or they act on other players, typically by killing them in a multi user dungeon sense.
But in the games with a purpose kind of sense there the people that you can actually use to say this player is not very good.
I'm going to kill them in an annotation sense, not an actual sense, and you can use them to clean up the data and to clean up the spam.
And that's what we're actually trying use.
And you perhaps you can use this kind of motivation framework for language learners as well.
Now, it may seem a bit odd to introduce the concept of killers into a language learning environment, but someone who can go around and say no, sorry your your English is wrong here.
I suppose killers would be, you know those kind of dependents police on Facebook that go around correcting peoples grammar.
You know.
So you missed an apostrophe there when you've been slagging things off that kind of thing.
So you're not really meant to read.
That is too small, but what we did was combine this concept of these of how we motivate these different types of people, or different different things in people's heads.
And we combine that with collecting user personas so we all sat around.
We had a sort of day long meeting we came up with personas of players, so this first one here.
You just make it up.
Write your paper and just imagine someone who could be playing your game so this one's age 18 student, extroverted, sporty needs to be thrilled.
Usually uses a phone like social things.
Engages quickly, often gets frustrated.
So we suspect that the best kind of kind of motivations for him will be.
Killing, killing, and the socializing.
That's the kind of thing that we want to try to appeal to that player.

And so we've got a whole list of user personas and we combine that with the motivation types, and that's how we start this developing games, and I personally feel as someone who developed the games that was a big step forward in trying to understand our users and deliberately trying to appeal to them.
'cause I think what we did in the past was we we we had a linguist, he said I've got a task.
How can I get loads of people to do it?
Let's make a game.
But if we push out and no one comes to it, Oh no, it's a disaster.
Let's throw some money at it, get some financial prizes.
You know that's just a common story for everyone who developed these systems.
You need to think about the users first.
You need to think about your players or your language learners or whatever it might be.
You need to think about them first and how you engage with them.
If you do it that way around your platform, I think is more likely to be a success.
So this is a Richard comes up with many amusing quotes, but I think this is one of his finest.
The Zeigarnik effect is something that you put into place in games and also language language learning platforms where where people strive to get to the next level.
So what you find is that people will get to the next level and they stop playing.
And what what Richard said about the zeigarnik effect was that if you collect X objects you won't want to stop and X -- 1 objects you want to finally get X of them.
And it's enjoyable, perhaps only in the same way that this stopping hitting your head with a hammer is enjoyable.
Hey, it's called a dry sense of humor.

I don't propose.
Maybe I should that we all agree a set of metrics that we release every time we release a paper about our games.

But I think having some kind of understanding as to what free to play games could offer us in terms of standardized metrics is a useful thing to have, and we have various papers available that go into more detail about those metrics if you're interested.
Alright, thank you.

So when we have a look at player metrics, these are metrics that really understand the interaction between the player, the platform and any kind of outside activity that's going on during a given time period.
So for example, advertising.
And the first one is cost per acquisition, so this is the cost to actually get a player to start playing your game now in free to play speech.
That's cost per acquisition, and that's basically the advertising budget over, say, a month divided by the number of new users that you get to your platform.
OK, that's a cost per acquisition.
But it's not quite that simple because obviously when you have an advertising campaign, it's not just run from one day to another date.
Well, it is, but you have a spillover effect, so people will still see that advert.
Perhaps people start emailing it to each other so you get a viral effect.
So you've got this kind of spillover virality going on.
And how do you detect between new and active users?
So how do you tell if someone seen the adverts?
Oh I remember that game.
I'll come back and play that game.

So the next one is lifetime judgments.
So in free to play speech, that's the customer lifetime value.
So how much money do they give you over the course of their engagement with your platform, minus the cost to get them onto your platform?
In in our kind of in a kind of world, that's just the total contribution to the game.
So how much contribution?
How many annotations or labels have they contributed?
Can we really put a monetary value on that contribution?

If we could, then we could then talk about we could reconcile that with the cost per acquisition, but that's slightly slightly complicated thing to do, and again, you have complications of returning users and the same actual physical person having different accounts, so there's complications with that.
The next metric is average judgment per person, and this is a very common one.

When you see free to play games called our ARPU average revenue per user and what that is is you take all of the revenue from the game over a time period divided by the total active users and that's a big kind of headline figure and in terms of our games it would be the average contribution over a period of time divided by the total active players.
But as I'm sure most of you aware, have built crowdsourcing platforms.
There is a zipfian distribution of work, so some people people contribute a lot.
Some people contribute a little bit and this figure is only headline figure.
It disguises that distribution.
And then the final one is the average lifetime play.
So how long the players continue to contribute over there over the time?

Or is it actual physical time that elapsed?

And then these two 2 idea idea idea is called retention and churn which are opposite of each other.
So the percentage of players who continue to play the game is retention and the percentage of players who stop is what's called churn.

So you might be spending money on prizes or advertising.
These kind of things to get people to actually play the game and to make a contribution to your system.

There's also the ongoing cost of the project or the platform, so your language learning platform, for example, might have to employ teachers and researchers to develop and the platform and for the software hosting all that kind of stuff, so that's that's the ongoing cost for useful contributions.
New platform.

The judgment required how many useful judgments are required to complete an item, so it might be that the contributions from a number of people you decide to throw them away because somehow you've measured that that person is not very good at the game, so you disregard their contribution.

It also depends on the aggregation methods you use, and there's lots of starting from majority voting onwards to Bayesian and network based things.
You can do for aggregation, and that's a whole whole different workshop entirely.
And it also depends on the difficulty of the items that you're that you're collecting data on.

So if you're crowdsourcing about a difficult language task, if you're doing a language translation task from English to Swahili or something where there's very few people who are able to do that well, you may have to look at the skill of players, and this may adjust the number of judgments that you require to actually get something done.
Then that allows us to get a headline statistically of the cost per item.
So this is what you would put into a Journal Journal, a project application if you like, and you would say normally we would collect this data in this fashion.
We employ some annotators and it costs this much, but we can use crowdsourcing and we estimate that it will cost this much and that is how you calculate it.
So it's the cost per item, so the cost of completely annotating a single item is the cost per judgment times the number of judgments you need.
And then you multiply that by the number of how much data you require from your project, and that's that's how you can build a budget from that.
And that's also compatible across not only compatible compatible across games, but also a different approaches as well.

So sometimes if you employ expert annotators, that might be different to employing students to do annotation that be slightly cheaper, but perhaps you'd employ three students rather than one expert or these kind of things so you can compare different approaches.
And then finally throughput which I mentioned before, which is the number of completed items you can produce in an hour.

So again, this gives you an idea of scalability of what you're trying to do, because if you say I want to annotate this 100 million word corpus, but it takes me, it takes me a day to get a document finished, then you multiply that up and you realize that it takes you take your 100 years to actually get your number of things done, so the throughput allows you an assessment of time, and then the this on the cost per item gives you an estimate of budget as well.
So these community metrics.
These sort of big headline platform metrics can give you an idea of whether your system can produce data fast enough.
How many players you need, and also whether a different approach might be better.

So yeah, couple of issues that we've come across in our project and then a couple of design ideas so.
When you're doing crowdsourcing, quite often you're collecting a majority voting opinion because you only have a single answer.

You have one correct answer and all the other answers are not as good or they're incorrect, OK, and that's you can compare that to an export an expert, so your game produces one answer and you compare that to an expert in a language learning sense.
You have the correct translation or the correct the correct interpretation of a sentence, and the language learner tries to put that in, and if they get it right, then yes.
And if they don't, then they have to be given some more training materials.
Few systems can produce a probabilistic answer set with ambiguity ambiguity.

That's what we're actually working on, and actually in language learning you might want to have that so you have the optimal answer, but perhaps if they put something not quite so good, it's still kind of correct, so they still get some recognition, and then they just get a bit of a bit of tuition as to how to make their sort of language learning outputs a bit better.

The thing is, it's very hard to distinguish between a correct minority opinion from an actual error, and this is what we found in our project we're working on at the moment is that if you have someone who's very good who puts in a very good answer and yet a lot of people put in not such a good answer.
Which one do you go for?
I don't know the answers, by the way.
These are ongoing research questions.

And so you have this value of a single good player versus many bad players, and the ability of your crowd generally has a very, very big impact on the kind of data that you're collecting in the kind of crowdsourcing that you can do.
One of the other issues that we've come across is the use of contextual real world knowledge that's required by the task.
So this is also something that plays into language learning as well as if you ask a question, you assume that people would know the answer.
So when we do anaphoric coreference in our games we were to talk about the Prime Minister of the UK and Theresa May.
We would assume that everyone knows that but not everyone would know that.
And it's the same with language learners as well.
There's certain contextual knowledge that you have to make explicit for people to solve the task.

And what we're trying to collect here is there's two types of human knowledge.
There's human knowledge that you have collected to the real world, knowledge, contextualization, knowledge, that kind of stuff.

But there's also the ability to solve problems using kind of human brain power and a lot of our language data collection uses this kind of real world understanding of language rather than the human brain power, whereas for example, the image processing an image labeling stuff often uses human brainpower.
So there's those different kinds of human computation going on there as well.

I am very fortunate to work with Richard Bartle, who's the guy who invented multi user Dungeons, so if any of you are old enough to have A to go to University or school and they had a computer room where all the birds went either like a BBC or Apple Mac or something like that really old one, these are the games that people were playing.
So you go on and you type in.
I'm going to kill the dwarf and then say you have killed the Wolf.
That comes in these multi user Dungeons.
He invented them.
And when he invented them, he notice that there were four different characteristics of players that were coming out.
There were people who were achievers and they like to achieve power and status and their fun and enjoyment from engaging.
The platform comes from leveling up and gaining points.
You have explorers, people who like to figure out the game to like find the full extent of the game and collect those kind of little hidden Easter eggs within within games and platforms.
You have people that you have socializes people who like to engage with the other users in the game.

And then you have people who are killers and killers, that people who typically like to do things that you don't expect, they cause trouble and they interact, or they act on other players, typically by killing them in a multi user dungeon sense.
But in the games with a purpose kind of sense there the people that you can actually use to say this player is not very good.
I'm going to kill them in an annotation sense, not an actual sense, and you can use them to clean up the data and to clean up the spam.
And that's what we're actually trying use.

'cause I think what we did in the past was we we we had a linguist, he said I've got a task.
